Efficient selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol with oxygen in a continuous fixed bed reactor over NiGa hydrotalcite derived catalyst Weiyou Zhou * Guanhu Chen Binxun Yu Jiacheng Zhou Junfeng Qian Mingyang He * Qun Chen Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Changzhou University, Changzhou, 213164, China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology Changzhou University Changzhou 213164 China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Changzhou University, Changzhou 213164, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A series of NiGa catalysts have been prepared by calcining Ni5Ga-LDH under different temperatures, detailedly characterized, and investigated in the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde in a fixed-bed reactor. The results indicated that calcination has a key effect on the composition of the catalyst and the catalytic performance, and the NiGa hydrotalcite calcined at 250 ℃ (Ni5Ga-LDH-250) exhibited the highest activity, which probably was due to the highest amount of surface basic site and the composition of Ni species. Under the optimized conditions, an excellent 91.5 % yield of benzaldehyde could be continuously obtained. Moreover, the catalytic performance kept almost steady in 170 h, and the catalyst could be regenerated and reused with slight reduction of the catalytic performance. According to the analysis of structure-activity relationship and the results of controlled experiments, possible reaction pathways for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol over Ni5Ga-LDH-250 are proposed. Keywords Benzaldehyde Layered double hydroxide Calcination Benzyl alcohol oxidation Fixed bed reactor 1 Introduction Benzaldehyde is an important and commonly used raw material for the production of fine chemicals for such applications as fragrances and botanical agents [1,2]. Hydrolyzation of benzyl chloride and oxidation of toluene are the two main commercial processes for the benzaldehyde production. However, these processes suffer from the production of chlorine-containing waste water and quite low-efficiency. In the current laboratory, benzyl alcohol oxidation by stoichiometric amounts of oxidant is the main method for the synthesis of benzaldehyde. However, the application of stoichiometric reagents, including manganese oxide or chromium salts, results in many drawbacks in cost and environment. Development of catalytic process for the production of benzaldehyde from benzyl alcohol is highly desirable. To date, many homogeneous or heterogeneous catalytic protocols have been studied for the reaction using various oxidants, such as H2O2 [3,4], TBHP [5], NaIO4 [6], molecular oxygen [7,8], etc. It is obvious that aerobic oxidation with heterogeneous catalyst is the most attractive from the economic, environmental and practical perspectives [9–11]. Various catalysts based on Au [12–14], Ag [15], Pd [16–18], Ni [19–21] and Mn [22–24], have been prepared and investigated. However, most of these processes are performed in tank reactor and in discontinuous pattern, which make the procedure complex and sometimes influence the stability of the catalyst for the formation and accumulation of by-product. In this sense, development of efficient catalyst and continuous process for the production of benzaldehyde still is an important industrial challenge. Some catalytic systems have been developed for the continuous process [25–30], but they always suffer the drawbacks of using precious metals, high temperature or low catalytic efficiency. Mesoporous ceria-zirconia solid solution has been developed by Pudukudy and coworkers for the vapour phase oxidation of benzyl alcohol, however, the maximum benzyl alcohol conversion was only 80 % with about 90 % selectivity to benzaldehyde [31]. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) is commonly known as hydrotalcites [32], have been widely studied as functional materials for its special properties [33–38]. In our previous work, we have found that the Ni-containing hydrotalcites can effectively accelerate the selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes using molecular oxygen as the sole oxidant [20,21] in carousel reaction tube. Some features have been observed for the catalytic system: (I) the catalytic efficiency was low, 0.5 g Ni-containing LDHs was required for the full conversion of 0.5 mmol benzyl alcohol; (II) the activity was high at the initial stage, and then reduced significantly, which probably was due to the formation and accumulation of H2O; (III) increment of the reaction temperature had little effect on the catalytic selectivity below 140 ℃, which makes it possible to conduct the reaction under high temperature to improve the efficiency. To develop efficient and practical process for the benzyl alcohol oxidation, the above observations prompted us to investigate the reaction in a vapor-phase continuous reactor, although sometimes it has a lower productivity than condensed phases. We speculated that higher temperature can be adopted and the produced H2O can be removed during the reaction, subsequently the catalyst can be stabilized and the catalytic performance will be improved. On the other hand, although hydrotalcites has been widely studied as catalysts in various reactions, very few report deals with the preparation of macroscopically structured particulate catalyst based on hydrotalcites, which is very vital for the application in a continuous process. In this context, a series of Ni-containing catalysts derived from hydrotalcites have been prepared and investigated in the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol in a vapor-phase fixed bed process. The effects of various reaction conditions, the stability of the catalyst and the regenerated method have been detailedly studied. The present LDHs-derived catalysts for the production of benzaldehyde from benzyl alcohol oxidation may have interest in a prospective industrial application. 2 Experimental section The chemical reagents used in the experiments are all analytically pure and were purchased from Energy-Chemical. 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Taking the preparation of Ni3Ga-LDH as an example: a solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.066 mol) and Ga(NO3)3·8H2O (0.022 mol) in deionized water (100 mL) and the other solution of Na2CO3 (0.1 mol) and NaOH (0.2 mol) in deionized water (100 mL) were poured into 100 mL deionized water in a 500 mL flask under vigorous stirring at 25 °C. The dropping speed was controlled to maintain the pH value at 10 ± 0.5. After that, the solution was stirred at 70 °C for 8 h, then aged at room temperature for 12 h. After being filtered, washed with deionized water, dried at 120 ℃, Ni3Ga-LDH was obtained. Ni3Al-LDH, Ni3In-LDH, Ni2Ga-LDH, Ni4Ga-LDH and Ni5Ga-LDH were prepared via similar procedures. Calcining Ni5Ga-LDH under 200 ℃ for 5 h gave the sample Ni5Ga-LDH-200. Through the similar methods, Ni5Ga-LDH-250, Ni5Ga-LDH-300 and Ni5Ga-LDH-400 were obtained. The characterization methods can be found in Supporting Information. Before being investigated, these catalysts were pressed and crushed to 20–40 mesh using a sieve. 2.2 The procedure for the benzyl alcohol oxidation The catalytic properties of the prepared catalysts were studied in a continuous flow fixed bed reactor (Ø6 mm × 300 mm), and 2 mL Ni5Ga-LDH-250 was packed in the isothermal region of the reactor. The other region was filled with sand. After being preheated at the selected reaction temperature for 1 h under an O2 flow rate of 5 mL/min, 5 vol% benzyl alcohol solution in toluene was introduced from the top of the reactor using a piston pump. The residence time was adjusted by changing the flow velocity of the benzyl alcohol solution. The reaction mixture was then cooled by water and collected in a gas-liquid separator. The reaction solution was analyzed by GC-FID (Shimadzu GC-2010AF) using internal standard method (chlorobenzene as the reference compound). The value for the conversion, yield and selectivity were obtained via the following formulae. Conversion ( % ) = moles of benzyl alcohol converted moles of benzyl alcohol in feed × 100 % Yield ( % ) = moles of benzaldehyde formed theoretical moles of benzaldehyde × 100 % Selectivity ( % ) = moles of benzaldehyde formed moles of benzyl alcohol converted × 100 % 2.3 Regeneration of the deactivated catalyst The deactivated catalyst (≈ 3.2 g) was taken out from the reactor and calcined under 450 ℃ for 4 h. Then the sample was added into 50 mL of Na2CO3 solution (0.2 mol/L) in a 100 mL round-bottom flask. Under vigorous stirring, the pH value of the solution was adjusted to about 7–8 using HCl solution (0.01 mol/L). Then the mixture was treated under 80 °C for 10 h for reconstruction. Then the reconstructed sample was filtered and washed to neutrality with deionized water. The obtained solid was dried at 120 ℃ and then calcined at 250 ℃ for 5 h, the regenerated Ni5Ga-LDH-250 was finally obtained. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening In the present study, the Ni-containing hydrotalcites catalysts were firstly screened. For the samples with different trivalent metallic ions, the characteristic hydrotalcite reflections can be obviously observed from the powder XRD patterns (Fig. S1). The sharp (003), (006) and (009) planes can be found at about 11°, 22°, and 35°, respectively, indicating the formation of a layered structure [39–41]. Moreover, the diffraction peaks of the (110) and (113) crystal faces appearing around 2θ = 60° indicate the ordering of anions and cations in the structure [42,43]. In the catalytic oxidation with benzyl alcohol as the substrate, Ni3Ga-LDH exhibited the highest catalytic activity (Table S1), and a 42.2 % conversion could be observed with 95.3 % selectivity to aldehyde, where benzyl benzoate was identified as the main byproduct by GC–MS analysis. The varied surface basicity of these samples may be responsible for the results [20,21], which has been observed significantly affected by the trivalent metal ions. According to the obtained results, some NiGa hydrotalcites with various Ni/Ga ratios were prepared, because the ratio of M2+/M3+ has significant effect on the physico-chemical properties. The XRD spectra of these samples in Fig. S1 show that NiGa LDHs with different Ni/Ga ratios have been successfully prepared. The catalytic activity in the vapor-phase oxidation of benzyl alcohol increases with the increment of Ni/Ga ratio, which is obviously different from the results in the batch reaction [20], implying the possible different reaction pathways in the two reaction systems. Since the highest amount of Ni in Ni5Ga-LDH sample, the above observations suggest that Ni plays a key role as active site in the reaction. In the following research, Ni5Ga-LDH was selected as the precursor to develop Ni-containing catalyst with higher catalytic performance for the benzyl alcohol oxidation in the vapor-phase continuous process. 3.2 Catalyst characterization Using Ni5Ga-LDH as the precursor, a series of calcined samples at different temperatures have been prepared, and the XRD patterns are depicted in Fig. 1 . After being treated under 200 °C, the main diffraction peaks [(003), (006), (009) and (110)] for Ni5Ga-LDH retain with the disappearance of (015), (018) and (113) peaks, which is mainly due to the lose of H2O on the surface and interlayer of the sample. When the calcined temperature was increased to 250 °C, the structure started to break down and the diffraction characteristic peaks (reflections at 2θ = 37°, 43.5°, 63°, and 75°) for the periclase-like structure of mixed oxides appear (Ni-Ga-Ox) [44,45]. It is worth noting that the peaks of (003), (006) and (009) for hydrotalcite still can be observed, indicating that the hydrotalcite structure was not completely collapsed. Further increasing the calcination temperature, the characteristic peaks for the hydrotalcite structure gradually disappear, and the pure phase of layered double oxide formed after treatment with 400 °C [46]. The shift of the peak (009) should be due to the different stoichiometries under varied calcination temperatures. It should be noted that no other type of phases from Ga can be found, suggesting that Ga was part of the crystalline brucite network with Ni. The N2-adsorption/desorption isotherms and the pore size distribution curves for these calcined Ni5Ga-LDHs with different calcination temperatures are shown in Fig. 2 and Table 1 . Fig. 2 shows that the isotherms of the four samples with different calcination temperatures are IV type, which is a typical mesoporous material based on the IUPAC classification of physical adsorption isotherms. And H2 type hysteresis loops are observed for all the prepared samples. The data in Table 2 shows that the BET surface area of those catalysts increase as the calcination temperature increase below 300 ℃ and decrease under higher temperature. And Ni5Ga-LDH-300 shows the highest value of 136 m2/g, while a value of only 79 m2/g is obtained for Ni5Ga-LDH-400. The pore volumes and average pore diameter change irregularly, which should be related to the change of the microscopic morphology, which results from the different compositions of these samples under various calcination temperatures. Since the surface basicity possibly plays an important role for the catalytic performance, the analysis of the basicity of these catalysts has been tried. However, the Hammett method cannot be conducted for the black color of the samples. And the pH values of the suspension of the prepared samples are not differentiable. CO2-TPD was introduced to analysis the surface basicity. The pretreated temperature was set at 200 ℃ to avoid the destruction of these samples. The results in Fig. 3 indicate that all the samples show both weak basic site (90 ̶ 150 ℃) and moderate to strong basic site (300 ̶ 500 ℃) on the surface. From the peak area, it is obvious that Ni5Ga-LDH-250 shows the highest amount of basic site in both types, while Ni5Ga-LDH-200 exhibits the least moderate basic site. The observation suggests that calcination benefits to the increase of moderate basic site, whilst too high calcination temperature will decrease the basic sites, especially for the weak basic sites. Similar results have been also observed in literatures for MgAl-LDH, where the partially decarbonated/dehydroxylated sample was substantially more basic than the corresponding metal oxides obtained through thermal decomposition [47,48]. Considering the characters of hydrotalcites, the interlayered OH− may responsible for the weak basic site, and the moderate basic sites may be originated from Ni‒O and Ga‒O pairs [49], produced under appropriate calcination. The results are in good agreement with Rao’s report, water in the structure of hydrotalcite inhibits the stronger basic sites [50]. TG/DTG analysis was also conducted. The curves of Ni5Ga-LDH-200, Ni5Ga-LDH-250 and Ni5Ga-LDH-300 (Fig. S2) involve two peaks for the weight loss. The first stage is related to the release of the surface and interlayer H2O molecule, and the other one can be ascribed to the dehydration of hydroxyl groups on the brucite layers and the loss of CO2 from the interlayer [51,52]. These observations indicate that the LDO were incompletely formed below 300 ℃. In contrast, only one obvious stage of weight loss related to the release of absorbed water can be observed for the Ni5Ga-LDH-400 sample, suggesting the pure Ni5Ga-LDO phase formed, which can also be elucidated by the only about 8 % loss of weight. As a result, the contents of Ni and Ga increase as the calcined temperature increase, which can be concluded from the ICP analysis (Table S2). The Ni/Ga mol ratio almost do not change, implying that no leaching of Ni or Ga happened during the calcination. XPS analysis of these prepared samples was used to assign the chemical environments of the nickel compounds formed during calcination (Fig. 4 ). According to the reported results in literatures [53–55], Ni5Ga-LDH-200 is mainly composed of Ni(OH)2, the typical composition of Ni-containing hydrotalcite. Concerning to the samples treated under 250 ℃ and 300 ℃, the XPS spectra of the Ni 2p3/2 can be fitted by three peaks, and binding energies of ca. 854.6 eV and ca. 857.9 eV are identified to NiO [53,56,57], while ca. 856.1 eV refers to Ni(OH)2 [53,54]. The observations indicate the multiple nickel species on the surface for the two samples, as observed by X-ray diffraction. As expected, only NiO species can be found in the XPS spectrum of the Ni5Ga-LDH-400 sample [53,56,57]. The compositions of Ni species for the four samples based on XPS analysis are summarized in Table S3, and the contents of Ni(OH)2 and NiO varied with the calcined temperature. The DR UV–vis spectra for the calcined Ni5Ga-LDHs (Fig. S3) also demonstrates the Ni2+ species in octahedral position [49,58,59]. Identification of species in the XPS spectra was also guided by the chemical shifts in the O 1s spectra. The overall O 1s spectrum is generally composed of three major species, lattice oxygen for metal oxides at ca. 530 eV, hydroxides at ca. 531.5 eV and chemisorbed oxygen at ca. 533 eV [53]. Analysis of O 1s spectra for Ni5Ga-LDH-200 indicate that the hydrotalcite almost did not collapse (Fig. 5 ), while that of Ni5Ga-LDH-250 and Ni5Ga-LDH-300 reveal that metal hydroxide and oxide formed on the surfaces. The ratio of OH̶/Olattice should relate to the nature of surface oxides, indicating the transformation of Ni(OH) to NiO, and almost pure nickel oxide is obtained with treatment at 400 ℃. These results are consistent with the XPS analysis result of Ni 2p3/2. The FT-IR spectra of the samples treated with different temperatures are shown in Fig. S4. The bands between 3250 ̶ 3500 cm−1 correspond to hydroxyl-bond stretching vibrations in the layers of hydroxyls and/or interlaminar water molecules in all samples [43]. The band for Ni5Ga-LDH-200 appears at lower wavenumber (3423 cm−1) and has a relatively smaller half-width than other samples, indicating there is a more-ordered cation distribution in the former [60]. The absorption peak at 1630 cm−1 further verifies the presence of water on the surface or in the interlaminar structure of the sample. The sharp band at 1384 cm−1 is related to the bending vibration of carbonate anion in the interlayers. The transmittance of the peak decreases as the increment of the calcination temperature, indicating the significant loss of carbonate anion. The SEM images depicted in Fig. 6 indicate that spherical-like morphology of Ni5Ga-LDH-200 can be observed. After being treated under 250 °C and 300 °C, the structure began to collapse, and changed to flocculent. Further, the catalysts collapsed completely while the calcination temperature reached 400 °C. The TEM images for these samples also show the similar structure and the agglomeration of irregular nanoparticles (Fig. S5). The lattice stacks for the Ni and Ga hydroxides or oxides can also be found in the TEM images. These observations are consistent with the results of the XRD, TG-DTG and FT-IR analysis. 3.3 Catalytic activity of Ni5Ga-LDH derived samples Prior to the investigation of the catalytic performance of these prepared catalysts, the solvent needed to be determined. Toluene is always chosed in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol for its dissolving capacity and inertness [21–23]. However, Enache et al. reported that toluene was produced as a byproduct in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol under the catalysis of Pd/TiO2 [61]. To check if toluene formed in the present catalytic system, the oxidation was initially conducted without solvent. After carefully analyzing the products formed in the reaction, only the product benzaldehyde and benzyl benzoate as the byproduct were observed, and no toluene could be detected. Furthermore, various solvents, including mesitylene, p-xylene, m-xylene and cyclohexane, were tested in the present catalytic process, and also no toluene could be observed. These results suggest that the formation of toluene did not happen in the present catalytic system. On the other hand, when cyclohexane was used as the solvent, lower conversion of benzyl alcohol was obtained than that in toluene (Table 2). Although mesitylene, p-xylene and m-xylene gave similar conversion and selectivity for the oxidation, some oxidation products, mainly the corresponding aldehydes, formed from the solvent could be observed, suggesting that they are not suitable for the present catalytic process. Further, when only toluene was introduced into the reaction system, no oxidation product could be found. These controlled experiments suggest that toluene is a suitable solvent in the present catalytic system. 3.3.1 Effect of calcination temperature Calcination changes the compositions and morphology of the catalyst, and thus affects the catalytic performance. The Ni5Ga-LDHs calcined respectively at 200 °C, 250 °C, 300 °C and 400 °C, were investigated in catalytic aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol in a continuous fixed-bed reactor. The calcination temperature demonstrates a key effect on the catalytic performance (Fig. 7 ), and Ni5Ga-LDH-250 exhibited the highest catalytic activity with a 92.3 % conversion. The results are probably ascribed to the surface basicity instead of the microscopic morphology, because Ni5Ga-LDH-300 with the highest specific surface area did not exhibit the best catalytic activity. Combining the CO2-TPD analysis, the amount of moderate basic sites should play the key role on the catalytic activity. On the other hand, although the contents of Ni and Ga are higher for the sample Ni5Ga-LDH-400, it did not give better catalytic activity, suggesting that the amounts of metals are not the key factor. Concerning the compositions of the four samples (Fig. 4 and Table S3), we speculate that the coexistence of Ni(OH)2 and NiO may benefit to the catalytic performance. In addition, all the catalysts exhibited excellent selectivity of benzaldehyde, which provides the possibility to obtain high-quality product. 3.3.2 Effect of reaction temperature Since the calcination temperature for Ni5Ga-LDH-250 was 250 ℃, the reaction temperature was tested below the value to make the catalyst composition unchanged. It can be observed from Fig. 8 that the conversion increased as the temperature increase, while the selectivity remained above 99 %. The phenomenon indicates that reaction temperature plays a key role in the oxidation, and almost no byproduct formed under the selected conditions. Further increasing the temperature led to a decrease of the selectivity for the formation of benzyl benzoate as the by-product. 3.3.3 Effect of reaction pressure The reaction pressure was also investigated in the benzyl alcohol oxidation process. When the reaction was performed under from atmospheric pressure to 0.5 MPa, the conversion of substrate increased from 79 % to 92.3 %, and little effect on the selectivity was observed (Fig. S6). Further increasing the pressure to 0.8 MPa led to only slight improvement, suggesting that 0.5 MPa is sufficient for the catalytic process. In summary, Ni5Ga-LDH-250 presents excellent catalytic activity for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol using molecular oxygen as the oxidant to benzaldehyde in vapor-phase fixed bed reactor. And the catalytic system probably provides a continuous process for the production of benzaldehyde. 3.4 The catalytic stability of Ni5Ga-LDH-250 catalyst The catalytic stability of the Ni5Ga-LDH-250 sample was then tested in the vapor-phase continuous process in a fixed bed reactor. The results (Fig. 9 ) reveal that the conversion of substrate remained basically unchanged until 120 h, and gradually decreased with the extension of reaction time. The conversion of benzyl alcohol decreased to about 90 % of the initial value at 170 h. Then the catalyst significantly deactivated. However, the selectivity of benzaldehyde remained constant above 99 %. Taking the 48.8 % content of Ni in Ni5Ga-LDH-250 into account, The TON (turnover number) has been calculated to be about 25.3, about 80 times higher than that in batch reactor [20]. The obtained results suggest that the influence of produced water in the reaction could be eliminated. To study the causes for the deactivation, the deactivated catalyst was analyzed by XRD, TG/DTG and N2-adsorbtion/desorption. The XRD pattern (Fig. S7) indicates that the diffraction peaks of the structural characteristics of the hydrotalcite [(003) and (006)] disappear after the reaction, and only the NiGa-LDO phase remains, demonstrating the collapse of the hydrotalcite structure. It can also be verified by the TG/DTG curves (Fig. S8), where the stages for the lose of the interlayer hydroxyl and water molecules and carbonate ions can not be observed. A significant weight loss around 423 °C can be found in the TG/DTG curves, which is probably due to the formation of coke. Actually, the C species can be obviously observed by XRD analysis with diffraction peak appearing around 2θ = 27° [62]. The results of N2-adsorbtion/desorption analysis in Table 2 obviously show that the specific surface area and pore volume of the used catalyst significantly decrease, which should be mainly ascribed to the generation of coke. The pH of the suspension of the used catalyst decreases from 9.79 to 7.14 (Table 1, entry 5), suggesting the weakening of the surface basicity. Taking the account of the XRD and TG/DTG analysis results, the change should be related to the decomposition of the catalyst and the coverage by the formed coke. These results further imply that surface basic sites of the catalyst and the compositions of Ni species may play important role in the catalytic oxidation [20,63]. Base on the above results and analysis, it may be concluded that the decrease of specific surface area and the surface basicity of the catalyst and the changes of the compositions, which result from the formation of coke and the decomposition of the catalyst, should be responsible for the deactivation. To regenerate the deactivated catalyst, the used catalyst was treated under 450 ℃ for 4 h and reconstructed by the “memory effect” of hydrotalcite-like compounds. The reconstructed Ni5Ga-LDH exhibits the typical diffractive patterns of hydrotalcite (Fig. S6). However, the intensities of some reflections are slightly different, possibly demonstrating different degrees of crystallinity. After being treated under 250 ℃, similar XRD pattern of the regenerated sample with the fresh catalyst can be observed. However, the specific surface area increases from 97 to 125 m2/g, which should be related to the decrease of the average pore diameter. The regenerated Ni5Ga-LDH-250 was then further tested in the oxidation. The results manifested that almost no decrease of catalytic performance was observed at the initial stage. But then, the conversion of benzyl alcohol gradually decreased, about 100 h was observed when about 90 % of the initial value obtained. The reduction of the catalytic performance for the regenerated catalyst might be due to the changes of the crystallinity of the restructured NiGa hydrotalcite. On the other hand, the results might also be ascribed to the decrease of the pore diameter, which can influence the movement of the molecule in the pore. However, these results strongly suggest that the regeneration process is effective. 3.5 Discussion of mechanism To get insight of the possible catalytic pathway, some controlled experiments have been performed. Ni5Al-LDH-250 and Mg5Ga-LDH-250 were prepared for comparison, because the Mg2+ and Al3+ are the common compositions of LDH compounds. From the results in Table 3 , the order of the catalytic activity of the three samples is as follows: Ni5Ga-LDH-250> Ni5Al-LDH-250> Mg5Ga-LDH-250, and only 0.6 % conversion was obtained when silica sand was used instead of catalyst (Table 3, entry 4). These observations suggest that Ni in the structure plays the leading role in the catalytic oxidation. Considering the surface basicity of these catalysts, as well as the Ni5Ga samples with different calcination temperature, it can be inferred that the surface basicity and the compositions of Ni species significantly affect the catalytic activity. The speculation can also be verified by the deactivation phenomenon of the catalyst. In addition, the experiment was performed with catalyst in the absence of oxygen (N2 was used in place of O2), the reaction was still possible under nitrogen, although the conversion of benzyl alcohol was very low (Table 2, entry 5). These results suggest that lattice oxygen in the catalyst structure is effective for the formation of carbonyl compound. Then, Ni5Ga-LDH-400 consistent of metal oxide, and Ni5Ga-LDH-200 hydroxide were tested under N2 atmosphere. Ni5Ga-LDH-400 gave a 7.1 % conversion of benzyl alcohol, while only 3 % was observed for Ni5Ga-LDH-200, suggesting that lattice oxygen in the metal oxide might responsible for the catalytic activity without molecular oxygen. Correspondingly, oxygen is required for the catalytic transformation in the case of hydroxide. Based on the above obtained and reported results [19,21,35], we proposed that the aerobic oxidation of alcohol over Ni5Ga-LDH-250 probably underwent by two reaction pathways. For the metal oxide species (Scheme 1 , path I), alcohol reacts with M‒O basic site to form alkoxide anions. Then hydride transfers from the alcoholate to the Ni atom next to the M‒O. Then, the corresponding carbonyl product formed, accompanied by the nickel hydride species. Finally, the nickel hydride species reacts with adsorbed molecular oxygen to complete the catalytic cycle. For the hydroxide, the alcohol molecule reacts with the Brönsted OH group of the brucite to form alkoxide (Scheme 1, path II). At the same time, oxygen is activated at the position of Ni [19]. Then hydride transfer takes place from the alkoxide bonded to Ga to the peroxide to form carbonyl product, with regeneration of an OH anion of the brucite layer. This in turn reacts with a fresh alcohol to give alkoxide and initiate another cycle. 4 Conclusions In the present research, various Ni-containing hydrotalcites with different trivalent metal ions have been investigated in the benzyl alcohol oxidation using molecular oxygen as the oxidant in a continuous fix-bed process, and Ni5Ga-LDH showed the highest catalytic activity. Moreover, a series of catalysts have been prepared using Ni5Ga-LDH as the precursor by calcination under different temperatures, and systematically characterized. The results indicated that calcination has significantly effect on the composition and surface basicity of the catalysts. The partially decarbonated/dehydroxylated sample is substantially more basic than the hydrotalcite and the metal oxides formed by thermal decomposition. And Ni5Ga-LDH-250, composed of mixed Ni(OH)2 and NiO species, showed the highest surface basicity and catalytic activity in the present oxidation. The effects of conditions on the reaction have also been studied, and excellent catalytic results have been obtained in the fixed bed process. The influence of the by-product water in the batch reaction can be eliminated and no significant decrease in activity after 170 h continuous reaction. In addition, the reasons for the deactivation of the catalyst were proposed mainly due to the carbon deposition and complete collapse of the hydrotalcite structure. The regeneration of the deactivated catalyst has also been studied in the present research, and good recyclability was observed. However, the regeneration method should be further systematically studied in our future research. The possible reaction pathways have also been proposed based on the obtained results and controlled experiments. coredata.dc:description: A series of NiGa catalysts have been prepared by calcining Ni5Ga-LDH under different temperatures, detailedly characterized, and investigated in the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde in a fixed-bed reactor. The results indicated that calcination has a key effect on the composition of the catalyst and the catalytic performance, and the NiGa hydrotalcite calcined at 250 ℃ (Ni5Ga-LDH-250) exhibited the highest activity, which probably was due to the highest amount of surface basic site and the composition of Ni species. Under the optimized conditions, an excellent 91.5 % yield of benzaldehyde could be continuously obtained. Moreover, the catalytic performance kept almost steady in 170 h, and the catalyst could be regenerated and reused with slight reduction of the catalytic performance. According to the analysis of structure-activity relationship and the results of controlled experiments, possible reaction pathways for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol over Ni5Ga-LDH-250 are proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol with oxygen in a continuous fixed bed reactor over NiGa hydrotalcite derived catalyst
